variant.question: The speed for best rate of climb is called:

A climb gradient required is 3.3%
 For an aircraft maintaining 100 kts TAS (no wind), this climb gradient corresponds to a rate of climb (ROC) of approximately
A headwind component increasing with altitude, as compared to zero wind condition, (assuming IAS is constant)...

options.text: has no effect on rate of climb.
decreases angle and rate of climb.
improves angle and rate of climb.
does not have any effect on the angle of flight path during climb.

variant.question: In unaccelerated climb:

options.text: thrust equals drag plus the downhill component of the gross weight in the flight path direction.
lift equals weight plus the vertical component of the drag.
lift is greater than the gross weight.
thrust equals drag plus the uphill component of the gross weight in the flight path direction.

variant.question: During climb with all engines, the altitude where the maximum rate of climb reduces to 100 ft/min is called:
To obtain a positive rate of climb

options.text: power required must be less than the power available.
thrust must exceed drag by the greatest margin.
power available must be equal to power required.
power available must be less than the power required.

variant.question: The rate of climb

options.text: is approximately climb gradient times true airspeed divided by 100.
is angle of climb times true airspeed.
is the downhill component of the true airspeed.
is the horizontal component of the true airspeed.

variant.question: The rate of climb

options.text: the still-air gradient multiplied by the TAS.
the still-air gradient divided by the TAS.
the angle of climb divided by the TAS.
the angle of climb multiplied by the TAS.

variant.question:
A 4.6% climb gradient is required to 1800 ft in order to clear an obstacle. TAS 125 kts Headwind 25 kts
What is the required rate of climb?
The rate of climb is approximately equal to:

options.text: the still-air gradient multiplied by the TAS.
the angle of climb multiplied by the TAS.
the still-air gradient divided by the TAS.
the angle of climb divided by the TAS.

variant.question: In order to achieve the maximum rate of climb, aircraft should be flown at the indicated airspeed which
During a climb with all piston engines operating, the altitude where the rate of climb reduces to 100 ft/min is called:

The minimum safe rate of climb following a SID profile is 6.1% to 1800', then 5% to FL30. TAS with T/O flaps 130KT, clean 230KT. Airport elevation  = 6', QNH = 1013, wind is calm.
The minimum safe rate of climb up to 1800' is:

options.text: 800fpm to a non standard acceleration altitude of 1800'

variant.question: Consider a graph showing the rate of climb on the vertical axis and the speed on the horizontal axis.

options.text: A tangent which is drawn from the origin will intercept the graph on a specific location which shows VX and the peak of the graph shows VY.
A tangent which is drawn from the origin will intercept the graph on a specific location which shows VY.
A tangent which is drawn from the origin will intercept the graph on a specific location which shows VY and the peak of the graph shows VX.
The peak of the graph shows VX.

variant.question: Consider a graph showing the rate of climb on the vertical axis and the speed on the horizontal axis.

options.text: A tangent which is drawn from the origin will intercept the graph on a specific location which shows V~X~ and the peak of the graph show V~Y~.
A tangent which is drawn from the origin will intercept the graph on a specific location which shows V~Y~ and the peak of the graph show V~X~.
A tangent which is drawn from the origin will intercept the graph on a specific location which shows V~Y~.
The peak of the graph shows V~X~.

variant.question: Which of the equations below expresses approximately the unaccelerated percentage climb gradient for small climb angles?

Given
  Still Air climb gradient 5%
 TAS 200 kts
 Wind component 50 kts tail
 What is the effective wind climb gradient?
The best rate of climb at a constant gross mass:

options.text: decreases with increasing altitude since the thrust available decreases due to the lower air density.
increases with increasing altitude since the drag decreases due to the lower air density.
increases with increasing altitude due to the higher true airspeed.

variant.question:
Given
  Still Air climb gradient 7.5%
 TAS 140 kts
 Wind component 25 kts head
 What is the effective wind climb gradient?
What is the best combination of slats and flaps for climb performance?

options.text: Small slat angle, small flap angle.
Small slat angle, large flap angle.
Large slat angle, small flap angle.
Large slat angle, large flap angle.

variant.question: When the outside air temperature increases, the climb gradient will...

options.text: increase, due to a higher true airspeed.
increase, due to a greater lift coefficient.
increase, due to a lower drag coefficient.

variant.question: The speed for best rate of climb is called..
The speed for maximum rate of climb:

options.text: will be higher than the speed for best angle of climb.
may be higher or lower than the speed for best angle of climb depending on aircraft type.
will be the same as the speed for best angle of climb under any circumstances.
lower than the speed for the best angle of climb.

variant.question: If cruising into a 15 kt headwind and a 180° turn is made so the wind is directly behind the aircraft, the IAS would:

options.text: be the same and the ground speed would increase by 30 kt.
decrease by 15 kt and the ground speed would increase by 15 kt.
increase by 30 kt and the ground speed would remain the same.
be the same and the ground speed would increase by 15 kt.

variant.question: The maximum rate of climb that can be maintained at the absolute ceiling is:
The maximum rate of climb that can be maintained at the absolute ceiling is:
To maintain climb airspeed following an increase in temperature the rate of climb is
The best speed for obstacle clearance is:

options.text: VX and no high lift devices.
VY with optimum flap setting for runway length, take-off weight and atmospheric conditions.
VX with optimum flap setting for runway length, take-off weight and atmospheric conditions.

variant.question: With increasing altitude, the rate of climb

options.text: decreases because power available decreases and power required increases.
decreases because power available decreases and power required is constant.
increases because density and drag decrease.
decreases because power available is constant and power required increases.

Calculate the obstacle clearance above a high tension cable located 1 NM from the DER (departure runway end) for a Class B piston aircraft.
Given:

- Runway 09
- Climb Gradient 5 %
- TAS 133 kt
- Tailwind Component 10 kt
- Slope 0 %
- Cable Height 104 ft

Height Difference = ((GD x climb gradient) / 100) x (TAS/GS)
Which of the following statements with regard to the actual acceleration height at the beginning of the 3rd climb segment is correct?

options.text: The minimum value according to regulations is 400 ft.
A lower height than 400 ft is allowed in special circumstances, e.g. noise abatement.
The minimum value according to regulations is 1000 ft.
There is no legal minimum value, because this will be determined from case to case during the calculation of the net flight path.

variant.question: Two aircraft of the same mass in ISA, one at M0.74 the other at M0.76. Which one has a greater Rate Of Climb (ROC)?
Which of the following statements is applicable to the acceleration height at the beginning of the 3rd climb segment?

options.text: The maximum acceleration height depends on the maximum time take-off thrust may be applied.
There is no requirement for minimum climb performance when flying at the acceleration height.
The minimum legally allowed acceleration height is at 1500 ft.
The minimum one engine out acceleration height must be maintained in case of all engines operating.

variant.question: You have commenced the descent. You have been instructed to keep the speed high and have been issued an altitude restriction of FL120 at a waypoint 50 NM ahead. You notice that you will not be able to meet this restriction with your current planned rate of descent. What should you do?

options.text: Increase your rate of descent while increasing your MACH to below MMO until the crossover altitude, where you fly an IAS below VMO. If needed deploy speed brakes to remain on the descent profile.
Decrease your rate of descent while increasing your IAS to below VMO and keep this speed until reaching FL120. If needed, deploy speed brakes to remain on the descent profile.
Increase your rate of descent while increasing your MACH to below MMO and keep this speed until reaching FL120 If needed, deploy speed brakes to remain on the descent profile.
Decrease your rate of descent and keep your calculated descent speed. If needed deploy speed brakes to remain on the descent profile.

variant.question: You are close to your 1.3 G buffet boundary when ATC instructs you to climb due to possible traffic, what should your response be?

options.text: "Unable to comply due to the 1.3G buffet margin."
"Roger, we will have to refer to our SOP’s before we are able to do so."
